titleStmt.title: T.H. Lacy's Acting Edition of Victorian Plays (1848-1873) : a bibliography
titleStmt.author: Revised and extended by Lou Burnard

sourceDesc.p: This is an enhanced and extended version of the catalogue of Lacy's Acting Edition originally created by the now sadly defunct Victorian Plays Project, directed by Dr Richard Pearson at the University of Worcester.

The catalogue has been cross-checked against several other sources of information. Various minor errors and inconsistencies have been corrected, and additional information added, particularly about available digitizations of the plays.

Each entry in the catalogue has been given a unique identifier beginning with "L", followed by a four digit sequence number; these "Lacy numbers" correspond with the numbers used in the original published lists and individual text copies. In a few cases, Lacy appears to have replaced one or more titles in the printed volumes subsequent to their first appearance (seebelowfor details); these replacement titles have been given an identifier suffixed with an R.

Authors' names have been standardised, in the form "Surname, Forenames-or-initials" following the most frequent usage in cases of doubt. Square brackets are used to indicate that the author name contained within them is not attested in this form on the title page of the work in question; sources for such attributions include Allardyce Nicoll's Handlists, the Adelphi Theatre Catalog, manuscript annotation of the source, presence of the title in a "By the Author Of" title elsewhere. Quotation marks are used to distinguish pseudonyms. In a few rare cases where no author is given and none has been plausibly identified, the author is given as "[Anon.]". In several cases, multiple author names are given.

The entry for each title begins with a main title, rendered in italics. This is followed by one or more subtitles, indicating the type and length of the piece, or its source in the case of a translation or adaptation, as given on the title page. This is followed by a note giving the date and location of the first performance, as indicated either by the source, or by the corresponding entry for this title in Nicoll's Handlists. Where this information is given by both sources, and differs, the earlier date is to be preferred, but both datings are retained.

[Taylor, Tom]; [Coyne, Joseph Stirling]The Vicar of WakefieldAn Original Drama in three acts60 pp (UW copy)New Strand Theatre4 March 1850J. Stirling Coyne is listed as the author of a play of this title on the title-page of his play "My Wife's Daughter" also in this Volume. However, in Volume 1, the anonymous play, "The Philosopher's Stone" is attributed to the author of "The Vicar of Wakefield" and "Diogenes", whilst "Diogenes" (Volume 1) is attributed to the author of "Parents and Guardians". This latter is known to be by Tom Taylor, and Nicoll lists Taylor as the author also of "The Vicar of Wakefield". It is plausible that this play was co-authored by Taylor and Stirling Coyne, although they are not known to have collaborated on anything else. "Sir Roger de Coverley" (Taylor) (Volume 4) is also listed as being by the author of "Diogenes", "The Vicar of Wakefield", "The Philosopher's Stone", and "Prince Dorus".N18931

div.head: Replacement titles
div.p: The selection of titles making up each volume seems to have changed very little during the course their long printing history. Certainly the lists of titles which appear occasionally in the printed volumes show little variation. However, a small number of titles do change between their first appearance -- if we are to believe the printed lists -- and their appearance in the 93-volume HathiTrust edition digitized by Google from a copy at the University of Michigan.The present catalogue includes both the original title, and its replacement, distinguished by the R suffix.For example, the sixth title in volume 1 has two versions, both given the number1.6. In the advertising pages consulted, this title is text L0006, Bayly'sLadder of Love. However, in the HT edition, the sixth title in volume 1 is Murray'sNo!, to which we therefore give the identifier L0006R. A list of these modifications follows. The dates given are those of the first performance according to the copy, where this is supplied.

div.p: The above table suggests that the replacement titles were almost always much older works, presumably available in house to replace any play which we may hypothesize Lacy had been cautioned against including since he had lost (or never held) the rights to it.
